descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
RTVF 322 Science Fiction Film & Television


This class explores the popularity of science fiction in postwar American culture-from late 1945 through the present. This period marks the aftermath of Hiroshima and the rise of television, space technologies, artificial intelligence and genetic engineering; in short, during this time there was a virtual explosion of scientific knowledge. Not coincidentally, science fiction became an extremely popular genre in film, pulp literature, and on television. These media texts used the new science for storytelling purposes, and in so doing transformed scientific change into speculation about social change and utopias.
This "speculative" aspect of science fiction will be the key concern of the course as we look at how the genre imagines social relationships between sexes, races, classes?as well as silicon and human life forms. What kinds of narrative strategies do these texts use to represent new social orders and relations? How has the genre changed over the last forty years, and in what ways can we make comparisons between generic changes and social changes? How has science fiction lent itself to self-reflexive exploration of cinema itself?especially cinematic time and space? And how does it build alternative futures or map dystopian nightmares? These questions form the focus of the various topics in the course. Evaluation is based on essay exams, a final paper/project, and oral presentations. Readings include articles, short stories, and books, and screenings will be required for each class (some screened in class, some on your own).

Required Books
Sobchack, Vivian: Screening Space: The American Science Fiction Film (New Brunswick: Rutgers, 1997)
Todorov, Tzvetan: The Fantastic: A Structural Approach to A Literary Genre (Ithaca: Cornell Up, 1973)
